http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When laying this system in 1871, the Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Company encountered bad weather which made it "necessary to cut and buoy the cable in 700 fathoms of water." Nonetheless, the company managed to complete the link on June 11, a mere twenty-four hours after its deadline.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Telegraph Bay, Pok Fu Lam, Hong Kong

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Barty-King: from here they connected to Eastern Extension office at Marine Hour – on the site occupied by Old Mercury House in 1979.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In nineteenth-century Hong Kong, a barrage of undersea cables – from Singapore, Shanghai, Fuzhou, Manila, Labuan, and Macau – landed at Telegraph Bay. From here, cables wound inland across the island’s northern shore, through the city center to the busy Eastern Extension cable office. The daily work of cablemen at “Electra House,” as it was called, was eventful. Traffic was re-directed from one network to another, messages linked local commerce into a global economy, and important political information was relayed about British-Chinese relations. Yet as they sustained the network, cablemen also worried about sustaining themselves. They were concerned about finding healthy food (one worried that local vegetables were not clean enough to eat) and about catching the plague (another remarked that “Hong Kong would not be Hong Kong if we didn’t have an epidemic of something every year”). And leading up to World War II, a cableman recounted, “Life in Hong Kong has been subject to rude jolts during recent years… we had quite a few delightful moments dealing with traffic which poured in for places which had been 'interrupted by bomb.'” Not long after, station life would be interrupted completely when the Japanese took over the island. Today the work of Hong Kong’s cablemen has moved to the island’s southern shore, but Telegraph Bay remains a center of information exchange. It is now the location of the expansive Cyberport, a “creative digital community” built to foster technology development.

You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, Saigon remained in the hands of the French, who finally laid their own system at the turn of the twentieth century. Leaving the city, transmission was slow at times: the government controlled the cable station and international messages sent during times of conflict could be delayed for at least an hour in order for censors to approve them. The cable itself comes ashore far from Saigon, about 50 miles away in rural Cape St. James. A report from the local hydrographic office noted that “the station at Cape St. James was a more healthy place than Saigon, [but] it had some drawbacks,” including potential “incursions of wild beasts. Large tigers were constantly prowling in the vicinity of the station… That the danger was not imaginary was proved by the killing of a large tiger on the verandah of the telegraph station.” Although the area is now a sprawling city and home to over 300,000, it continues to be a critical cable hub, with lines extending out to sea just a few miles around the cape.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1894-?; Telcon; Eastern Extension, Australasia China Telegraph Co; Scotia (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: An 1894 article about the cable in The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser observes that this system, a duplicate route between Singapore and Hong Kong, "is a work almost of supererogation, certainly one not required or justified by the existing traffic." At that point a single cable could still carry all of the traffic to and from China. Instead, the aim was "to give greater assurance and security to communication between India and Europe and between [Singapore] and China." By connecting the main naval base at Hong Kong with the other colonies (and stopping only on British territory), they predicted that the new cable would "materially increase the security of British interests in the Far East."

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb18940212.2.15.aspx

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Cable laid into Victoria Harbor, opposite government offices.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You surface on the shore of a tiny island off the northeastern coast of Malaysia. Nestled safely within the Brunei Bay, the spot is ideal for the traffic of signals, ships, and resources: the British once thought Labuan would become a "second Singapore." Initially occupied in order to combat piracy in the region, the island soon became the site of important British coal fields. British ships also stopped here as they traversed the South China Sea – the harvesting of coal made it both an export center and a fueling point for the Imperial Navy. The territory became a stopping-point for another network at the end of the nineteenth century: a cable was laid to connect Singapore and Hong Kong by way of Labuan. This flat, green island remained relatively unsettled by the British, who used it almost exclusively for its ore and harbor. Today, Labuan’s development continues to depend on its ocean-going history. Scuba divers come here to explore old sunken ships, oil and gas companies drill for modern energy sources, and corporations from around the world reap the benefits of the island's offshore financial center.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 12, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Commander of the Guard Ship, Ed. S. T., “Labuan – Coal Discoveries,” Hongkong Register, April 27, 1847, accessed August 12, 2013, http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/31752854.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Built by the Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company between 1901 and 1902, this cable was part of a larger project to connect Australia and London via British colonies in the Indian Ocean and South Africa.

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, staged theatrical performances, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, with no hills or mountains, these low-lying islands will face flooding in the coming years as climate change brings ashore ever-more intense storms.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the beginning of the twentieth century, Cottesloe turned to the ocean. The Perth-Freemantle Railway, opened just two decades before, had brought settlers and visitors to the coast. Beach-going was only a newly popular pastime, but by the early 1900s, thousands visited Cottesloe’s shores each weekend. Pine trees endemic to Norfolk Island, a Pacific island also populated by undersea cables, were planted to enhance the beach’s appeal. Around the same time, the Eastern Extension Cable Company extended a link across the Indian Ocean to Cottesloe. On the shore, they built a multi-story red brick building, where the signals came in as quickly as ocean waves. In 1937, the cable station manager boasted that “the only time throughout the entire year when there is a cessation of activity in these stations, is on Armistice Day, when the instruments are closed down for a period of two minutes.” Even though they were separated from the city of Perth, cablemen remained connected to urban life via the copper wire, at least until July 31, 1966, when the station finally closed. The cable itself remains, stretching across Cottesloe’s sandy beach, its insulation unfurling as it decays.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “A Fifteen Minute Broadcast Given by Mr. H. A. Colliver of Cottesloe Branch,” The Zodiac (1937): 276.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The British colony of Adelaide entered the underwater network in 1872. Telegraph signals traveled through overland lines to Port Darwin and, from there, to London via Singapore and India. Previously, messages between Europe and Australia were carried by ship and took upwards of eighty days to reach their destinations. Now they could be sent in a matter of hours. In 1901, Adelaide received its first submarine connection to the old world by way of Perth and Durban, South Africa. “Whilst buoying” the cable offshore near Kangaroo Island, notes an Eastern Extension Company cable ship officer, it “got foul of the propellers on account of the strong current; it took us six hours to get it clear, but no damage was done.” Once untangled, the line joined Adelaide’s General Post and Telegraph Office, a grand stone and brick building adorned with a clock tower. Built in the early 1870s to receive the first international telegraph signals, the station was soon expanded to include a telephone exchange.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1883-?; Telcon; Great Northern Telegraph Company; Store Nordiske (See AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: At the request of the Japanese government, the Great Northern Telegraph Company laid the first cable under the Korean Strait in 1883. The cable linked Nagasaki via Japan’s Tsushima Island to Pusan (now officially spelled Busan), the first international port in Korea and a major Japanese settlement.

This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it served as Japanese merchants’ primary access point to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Busan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority in Japanese. In 1931, Busan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission. Today, the city’s two cable stations, which provide a major gateway to the Internet, are finally operated by Korean companies. Yet the country faces another challenge at its shores – from local aquaculture rather than foreign powers. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s coast twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting the seaweed, fishermen come dangerously close to the country’s international communications lines. Whenever cable companies land a new system, they have to be careful not to disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Each cable must be carefully placed in a “mattress” before it is lowered down into the crop.

If you could climb up the deep green mountains on the northern end of this island, and look west across the water, you would see the hills of the Korean peninsula rising above Pusan. A small island, about 700 square kilometers of land, Tsushima is equidistant between the Japanese mainland and Korea. Because of its location, it had been a trade center for centuries before the cables arrived, and since has been a perfect locale for international cable connections as well as strategic military operations. Five different cables have landed here since 1891. In 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, a decisive battle was fought in the waters around the island, which the Japanese won largely through their adeptness with wireless telegraphy. Yet this did not lead to the scrapping of “older” cable systems. Quite the opposite. After the war, the Japanese immediately laid a new undersea telegraph cable: wires complement, rather than replace, wireless.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1883, the Great Northern Telegraph Company's line between Vladivostok, Nagasaki, and Shanghai was duplicated.

Founded in 1860 as a Russian naval post, the city of Vladivostok, “Ruler of the East," is fraught with contradictions. In the late 1800s, the military presence permeated the city, but the orderliness it instituted was offset by sailors’ gambling and drunkenness. At the same time, Vladivostok was a cosmopolitan center filled with a “polyglot crowd.” Businessmen from around the world were drawn by the city’s natural harbor and investor privileges. The Danish Great Northern Telegraph Company used Vladivostok as a connection point for their trans-Siberian cable and undersea links to Nagasaki and Shanghai – an important alternative to the British-dominated global network. The cable boosted the city’s international business as well as the dissemination of naval intelligence, and the telegraph company was granted a forty-year lease on a prime piece of land. Several cablemen were employed in a stately three-story office building to handle the traffic. In the 1930s, under Joseph Stalin’s repressive regime, Vladivostok changed profoundly. Many of its ethnic inhabitants were forcibly removed, and the city became a distribution point for Stalin’s political prisoners. Fearing espionage, the government removed foreigners from the Great Northern telegraph stations, and the cable line was left in Russian hands. In the following years, as Vladivostok changed from “colony of non-Russian powers” to a “city of workers,” multi-story apartment buildings were constructed where the telegraph office once stood, with statues of a worker, a farmer, a sailor, and a guard adorning the rooftop. Today the building has returned to its international roots: it is home to the Barbados Hostel.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As a key British treaty port in the wake of the first Opium War, Shanghai rapidly developed as a contact zone for international powers. The city brought together a mix of cultures, architectural styles, and social classes, but these connections were made possible by the exploitation of Chinese labor and a concession system that granted foreigners immunity to Chinese law. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, covertly brought ashore in the middle of the night by the Great Northern Telegraph Company. In the ensuing years more cables were laid without official Chinese sanction. Without the cooperation of the Chinese people, however, cables remained vulnerable to disruption. Enterprising pirates stripped cables for resale. Local villagers ripped down lines that disturbed ancestral grave sites and the landscape’s feng shui. Men armed with rifles had to patrol the Yangtze River to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the cable. The situation was ameliorated by degrees when, in 1875, the Chinese government offered official recognition and protection to the cables in exchange for ownership of the illegal lines upstream of Shanghai. A period of relative stability followed, as China slowly developed an overland monopoly on telegraph lines while colonial powers built ever more underwater connections.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Danish Great Northern Telegraph Company was a key player in the early telegraph network. The company was able to fund a system connecting parts of Europe and Asia in part due to the desire of Russia and other nations to have a secure communications route that ran independently of British links.

The Japan-Siberia cable (JASC), laid in 1969, was a true postwar international collaboration. The cable was manufactured in part by Japan's Ocean Cable Company and in part by the United States's Underseas Cable Corporation (all of whose previous cables had been supplied to the US military). The cable was then laid by both the Japanese ship KDD Maru with assistance from the Dutch Great Northern Telegraph Company. This kind of collaboration was a hallmark of the analogue era. It operated long beyond its system design life (which was only 20 years) up until 1996, when it was withdrawn from service and used for earthquake research.

It’s a typical grey day in Nakhodka. Looking out across the bay, you see large shipping vessels lingering beyond the oil rigs that dot the shore. Discovered in 1859 by a Russian warship seeking shelter from a storm, Nakhodka means “lucky find.” Despite its location on the edge of Siberia, the bay is both calm and ice-free, making it an optimal location for dropping anchor, as well as for surfacing cable systems. Nakhodka was the site for the landing of a telephone cable to Japan in 1969, followed by several fiber-optic links carrying Internet traffic. As is true for many of the postwar systems, this station is a relocation, over 100 miles, from the previous urban telegraph cable landing in Vladivostok. Similarly, the Trans-Siberian railway’s eastern terminus was shifted to Nakhodka in the 1950s, when Soviet authorities closed Vladivostok to foreign shipping. Then the only open port in the Russian Far East, Nakhodka grew rapidly from its trade and communications industries. Today, the small city of 150,000 still supports circulations across the ocean: shipping and receiving, fish processing and canning, oil exports and cable transmissions.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikipedia contributors, “Nakhodka,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhodka.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The only station on the west coast of Honshu, Naoetsu was linked to Russia by coaxial cable in 1969, followed by optical lines in the 1990s and 2000s. But this was not the town’s first entry into exchange networks. As early as the ninth century, its harbor bustled with merchant ships carrying rice, salted salmon, and fabrics for protection against the wet and snowy climate, later expanding to accommodate steamships and cargo vessels. Naoetsu is also the birthplace of Maejima Hisoka, Japan’s first Minister of Communications and so-called father of the postal system. After studying British mail delivery in 1870, he returned to Japan and set up a network of sixty-five offices between Tokyo and Osaka. By 1881, there were more than five thousand.

The last coaxial cable laid to Australia, AIS connects the country with Indonesia, Singapore, and the wider international phone networks routed through the Pacific Basin. Its inadequacies were already apparent at its inauguration in 1986, however. As one official’s speech notes, “More needs to be done. The International Information Age requires it of us.”

Surfacing at Whitford Beach, you are careful not to be hit by one of the sixteen-foot tall waves also making its way to the shore. This beach is beautiful and active: the hollow and powerful waves draw surfers from throughout the area and the soft sands bring visitors to lounge, fly kites, and ride horses along this sunny stretch of land. Several major international cables have also landed here, connecting Australia to Asia. About ten miles inland is the Perth International Telecommunications Centre (PITC), which occupies 710 square acres of flat, dry land in a rural suburb. Since 1986, the center has handled much of Australia's signal traffic. With its own power plant, and a 15-meter diameter antenna for communicating with spacecrafts, PITC is a stark contrast to the brick house on the shores of Cottesloe that welcomed the trans-Indian-Ocean telegraph cable in 1901.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: North of the original telegraph termination point at Weltevreden lies Jakarta’s post-independence cable hub. The area’s swamplands were once the home to the Dutch Fort Zouteland (“saline land”), and during the Japanese occupation of Jakarta during World War II, Ancol was the site of mass executions and burials. In films of the 60s and 70s, Ancol was portrayed as a mysterious and ghostly place. After Indonesia gained independence, the country’s founding President envisioned the transformation of Jakarta into a great international city, and coastal Ancol as a space for recreation, a “showcase of the nation.” His dreams were not recognized for decades, and even then, they came at a price. Developers dredged the nearby coast, destroying a beach that had made it accessible to Indonesia’s underclass, and converted the marshland for recreation facilities. Today, the theme park Ancol Dreamland, Sea World of Indonesia, resort hotels, and beaches are all accessible only with a fee.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.
Telegeography, “Submarine Cable Map,” accessed July 19, 2013, www.submarinecablemap.com.
“Ancol Cable Landing Station,” Submarine Cable Networks: The World of Submarine Cable Systems and Networks, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.submarinenetworks.com/stations/asia/indonesia/ancol.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Note: unconfirmed that SEACOM landed at Katong; not sure if image matches landing

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district from the early nineteenth century onwards. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.

Alongside a cable to Tschifu, the Russian post and telegraph service laid a cable from Port Arthur to Sasebo, in Japan. With the loss of the Russo-Japanese war, the Russians lost not only the port, but their cables.

Southwest of Dairen, at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula, Port Arthur was an important Russian naval base at the turn of the twentieth century. Valued in part because of its southern location and naturally protected harbor, the port gave the Russians year-round, ice-free access to the Pacific. The development of the port was only one part of a massive infrastructural expansion. The area served as a coaling station for the Russian fleet and a termination point for rail networks across the continent. In 1900, the Russians brought two telegraph cables ashore, one connecting south across the Yellow Sea to Tschifu, China and one connecting the longer distance west to Sasebo. This communications node would soon become Russia’s Achilles’ Heel: the cables were cut and intercepted by the Japanese leading up to and during the Russo-Japanese War. Unable to receive reports or warnings, Port Arthur was then surprised when Japanese ships attacked. The Japanese took control of the port and from here were able to wage a successful war for the control of Manchurian land and sea. Unrest may have started even earlier, however: in the year before the war, cable ships record trips to repair breaks in the Port Arthur – Tschifu cable, due to “willful cutting.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Sasebo became an essential node for military communications at the turn of the twentieth century. This Japanese port is about 100 miles south of the southern tip of Korea, across the ocean from Shanghai. The town had been a small fishing village until the Meiji Period, when it quickly became an important naval base because of its protected, nearly land-locked, deep harbor. In 1898, a major railway station was opened here, anticipating the other traffic to come. Cables came in from Port Arthur, and out across the East China Sea to Dairen and Tsingtau. The town grew up around the transiting traffic, becoming a busy port and a wireless station. Like many other hubs in the Pacific, its connectivity would become a liability in future years. The wireless station here is believed to have broadcasted the message to attack Pearl Harbor during World War II. Four years later, Sasebo suffered severe bombing by allied forces, and was on the list of potential targets for the dropping of the atom bomb.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The South-East Asia Communications system, a coaxial network laid in the mid 1960s, terminated in Cairns, Australia. Here it was linked via a microwave link to Sydney. But as one engineer recalls, this last wireless segment “was nothing but trouble. The cable would often just continually fail. Not because of the cable system, but the backhaul link between Cairns and Sydney.”

On the northwestern edge of Australia, Cairns gazes out across a serene blue-green sea. These peaceful waters are deceptive – underneath the surface there are mud flats, and farther out to sea, the Great Barrier Reef. The muddy, shallow bottom of the ocean means that Cairns is not the beach town it would seem destined to be. It caters primarily to tourists who stop by on their way to the reef, the area’s main attraction, which draws in flows of visitors every year, many of whom rely on the area's communications networks. In 1967, Cairns received its first cable: a link to Papua New Guinea, extending onward to Guam and Hong Kong. Nine years later, a second link was set up between Cairns and Papua New Guinea. The city remained a sort of branch outpost for Australia, a landing point for cables on the country's northern coast, until APNG was withdrawn from service in 1996. While its location at the tip of Australia makes it a natural outlet to Asia, the inland cable that connected these networks to Sydney has often caused problems, and the Great Barrier Reef, challenging to lay cables across, makes it difficult to bring signals in and out from abroad.

Madang is fairly small as far as cities go – about 30,000 people live here – but it is the capital and most populous part of its province. The city’s infrastructure is focused outward rather than inward. It is home to many of Papua New Guinea’s export industries, and the landing point for an international fiber-optic cable. The main occupation for many here is a large timber industry, which logs the nearby Gogol forest. In addition, the city exports copra, coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, and is home to tuna processing plants and engineering and joinery workshops. The people are also a mix – tourists, missionaries, and contract workers from countries around the world mingle with indigenous people speaking hundreds of different local languages. Papua New Guinea is considered one of the most culturally diverse places in the world, with over 300 different tribal groups living mainly in traditional societies. Only a small percentage live in urban, modernized centers like Madang and Port Moresby. But even cities within the country have trouble interacting with each other: the volcanoes that run through the middle of the island have prevented any roads from being built between them.

“Madang,” The Business Travel Report, http://www.thebtr.com, accessed July 10, 2013, http://www.thebtr.com/pages/australasia/cities/papuanewguinea/madang.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of a World War II Japanese antiaircraft gun at the far end of Gun Beach. Few realize that Guam's strategic military value during the war was in part due to its undersea cable networks. Even fewer realize that the island remains one of the most connected places in the Pacific, with cables stretching out from its shores to the mainland United States, Asia, and Australia. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five-star hotels in the area, a building dependent on the island’s advanced communications infrastructure. At Tumon Bay, undersea cables bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which cable communications are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, one can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned Guam at the center of transpacific movements.

The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

One legend has it that “Kinabalu,” the name of the tallest mountain in the Malay archipelago, is derived from the words for “Chinese Widow.” Long ago, a Chinese prince married a local Kadazan woman, and when he departed for China, he promised to return. She waited for him atop the mountain, where eventually she was turned to stone. In its early years Kota Kinabalu, then named Jesselton, depended heavily upon travelers from the sea. From Jesselton, ships and trains relayed goods with the help of both the British North Borneo Company, who administered the area, and Chinese merchants that funneled products to markets in mainland Asia. Undersea cables, though, bypassed Jesselton to link directly to the more prominent Labuan. Following World War II, when almost all of the city’s architecture and infrastructure was decimated, the town was reconstructed as the capital of North Borneo, which in 1963 gained independence. Major development initiatives were launched in this period, including the SEACOM undersea cable, which connected the city to Singapore and Hong Kong only a year afterward. Today Kota Kinabalu remains the economic and industrial capital of its state.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, atlantic_cable.com, accessed July 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Liu Ming-Chuan, Qing governor of Taiwan, ordered the construction of this telegraph cable. It was part of a larger modernizing effort and ethos of self-sufficiency in the newly established Chinese province after a prolonged conflict with France. Completed in 1887, the line was laid by Taiwan’s first cable ship, the Feicheu.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though they are sparsely populated, the Penghu Islands have long been linked to communications networks. In the late 1880s, at the order of the Qing governor of Taiwan, a telegraph cable connected Penghu to China in the east and Taiwan to the west. This was accompanied by gun emplacements meant to fortify the “militarily indispensible” island. Despite these measures, less than ten years later the islands were ceded to Japan along with Taiwan, a result of China’s defeat in the Sino-Japanese war. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked across the Taiwan Strait. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through. Today, the islands are linked to the rest of Taiwan via another kind of subsea technology: major undersea power cables link Penghu into Taiwan’s electric grid.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1887, a cable was laid from Anping harbor in Tainan, then the capital of Taiwan, to the Penghu archipelago on the order of Liu Mingchuan, an official in the Qing dynasty. The lack of trade between Tainan and Penghu meant that the cable “was of little importance to the commercial world,” explains American diplomat James W. Davidson. Yet “it was of great value from a political standpoint, the strategic importance of the [Penghu] islands demanding that they should be in communication with the capital.” This political value was short-lived, however, since the capital was moved north to Taipei later that year. Tainan has seen many such political fluctuations in its history. The Dutch established a fort here in the early 1600s, which was later taken over by Chinese military leaders, the Qing, the Japanese, and finally the Republic of China. Reconstituted under each new ruler, Tainen was nicknamed “The Phoenix City.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan. New York: Pelgrave Macmillan, 2005. 147.
James W. Davidson, The Island of Formosa Past and Present: History, People, Resources, and Commercial Prospects. London and New York: Macmillan & Co., 1903. 247.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Entering service in March 1999, this optical cable connects the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company’s station in Batangas with AT&T’s landing point in Guam, where connections are made to several Asia-U.S. networks. It was designed to complement and ease congestion along existing Asian and trans-Pacific cable systems.

You land in Nasugbu only a day after a typhoon has swept through the area, devastating local infrastructure and flooding many homes built on the broad beach. This small town, strategically located on the South China Sea only sixty miles from metro Manila, is the largest network hub in the Philippines. From here, direct circuits link to almost every Asian country. In the 1990s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company opened the country’s first international fiber-optic cable station, which towers over the palm trees and bamboo structures that line the beach. Just down the street is Globe Telecom’s newer facility, an anchor point for the Southeast Asia-Japan cable system. Large walls surround both stations, yet the place where cables enter the water is unmarked. On your journey back out to sea, you pass the remains of a Spanish galleon, sunk by the Dutch navy in 1600. Discovered in 1992, the shipwreck became one of the most important finds in underwater archeology. A replica, along with a museum and resort, were built on nearby Fortune Island but have since fallen into disrepair.

The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific, including Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Point Arena. Each has an image of the station and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

Fiber-optic cables encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass. Although in development since the early 1980s, the conservative cable industry did not lay the first transoceanic network until 1986. The immense capacity of fiber-optics have made possible the Internet as we know it today.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Verizon Business,  AT&T,  KDDI,  Tata Communications,  China Telecom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  NTT,  Level 3,  SingTel,  Sprint,  Telekom Malaysia,  Telecom New Zealand,  Telstra,  PCCW,  LG Uplus,  Softbank Telecom,  Rostelecom,  SingTel Optus,  France Telecom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before Bandon became AT&T’s outpost in rural Oregon, it was a critical node in an undersea cable network: the U.S. military’s Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS). From the Pacific coast, SOSUS connected hydrophones and picked up sonic traces of subaquatic movements, from the deployment of Soviet submarines to migrations of whales. Officers stationed at Naval Facility Coos Head tuned into these underwater listening posts and collected data on enemy operations. The Coos Head facility, first opened in 1958, was closed twenty-nine years later in 1987. Improvements in signal-processing had replaced manpower with computers, and as the Cold War wound down the number of Naval Facilities was reduced. Given AT&T’s tight ties with the U.S. Navy, and their assistance in developing SOSUS, it was unsurprising when nine years later, they chose Bandon as a landing point for their newest transpacific cable system, TPC-5.

This rural station in Central California has been a cable hub since 1964, when a telephone cable to Hawai'i was routed through Morro Bay. Constructed by AT&T, its location was midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles placed it out of the way of potential nuclear attack. Although the state has been a hub in communication technology, it has also played an important role in the growth of the environmental movement and the preservation of wilderness areas. Daniel Press articulates the apparent contradiction: “at the vanguard of paradoxical trends, California is one of the fastest growing states in the country, but is the most ambivalent about change.” Today, Central California is a site of conflict between these two forces. Fishermen and environmentalists regularly pose challenges to infrastructure development.

Completed in 2000, the consortium-owned China-U.S. Cable Network was the first direct cable route between the two countries. It consists of dual Pacific crossings, forming a ring structure with connections along the west coast of the U.S. and between several Southeast Asian hubs. Only a year after it entered service, however, the anchor of a fishing boat off Chongming Island disrupted much of the traffic between China and the U.S..

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Telekom Malaysia,  AT&T,  Starhub,  PLDT,  Communications Authority of Thailand,  airtel (Bharti),  Telstra,  Telkom Indonesia,  BT,  Eastern Telecom,  PT Indonesia Satellite Corp.,  Telecom New Zealand,  Viettel Corporation,  Saigon Postal Corporation,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Brunei International Gateway,  BayanTel

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: By the 1990s, capacity was filling up at Hong Kong’s major cable station, and the cable companies looked for a place to expand. Lantau Island, just west of the city of Hong Kong, seemed ideal. It was to be the site for major infrastructure developments during that period: a new international airport, a trans-bay expressway, and the AsiaWorld theme park were placed in what was otherwise a sprawling, sparsely populated jungle. The station builders chose Tong Fuk for their landing, a small village on the island’s southern shore. When they went to construct the station, however, the village leaders resisted, worried that the cable stations would disrupt the feng shui of the land and bring them bad fortune. The stations were ultimately placed there, but companies careful not to infringe upon the nearby shrine.

You arrive in Baccuit Sur, a coastal neighborhood in the town of Bauang, near resorts, dive shops, and stands that sell grapes and guava-apple hybrids from local farms. The two main segments of the Asia-America Gateway fiber-optic system meet at Bauang’s cable station, forming a bridge between Southeast Asia and the Pacific. Before it catered to beachgoers and network traffic, this former Spanish colony was a site of violent conflict. Moro pirates invaded Bauang several times in the 1800s, leading the town to construct a defensive network of cylindrical stone watchtowers along the coast. And when Japan occupied the Philippines during the Second World War, Japanese troops clashed with the local resistance movement on Bauang’s otherwise calm shores.

In 1962, the balance of undersea cable power was shifting from British companies to the Americans. The Keawa‘ula cable station had just been built on O‘ahu’s west shore to land the Commonwealth Pacific Cable (COMPAC). British and Canadian transoceanic lines no longer stopped at Fanning Island, but rather, on United States soil. As a result, the construction of their cable station accorded with U.S. military specifications: it was located underground in a nuclear fallout shelter with thick walls and a decontamination chamber. Arriving at this station today, you see an elegant set of steps up leading up to a front wall comprised of square glass blocks. One transmission engineer describes Keawa‘ula as a “palace.” Designed by a local Honolulu-based firm, the station's aboveground expansion was inspired by a visit from the CEO of Teleglobe Canada in the 1980s. With little space for gathering inside, the staff members at the time held their meeting in a small and cramped lunch room. Afterward, the CEO saw the station workers outside, joking around and hanging out in the trees. In part inspired by the cable community, Teleglobe built a new, staff-friendly environment. The re-designed station grounded the communication hub in the heart of the cable family, yet left intact its Cold War foundations.

Asia-America Gateway (AAG), opened in 2009, was the first high-bandwidth optical cable to provide a direct link between Southeast Asia and California (via the Philippines, Guam, and Hawai'i). Positioned further south than other trans-Pacific routes, AAG avoids the seismically active areas near Taiwan where earthquakes are known to cause cable disruptions.

This was the first submarine telegraph line to Australia, laid by the British Australian Telegraph Company in 1871. Here it connected to the Overland Telegraph, which stretched almost 2,000 miles south to Adelaide. Although the undersea cable reached Darwin before the terrestrial link, it was severed in the ocean only shortly thereafter. Finally, after the submarine cable was repaired, Australia was enfolded into the British colonial network.

Banyuwangi means "Fragrant Water" in Javanese. Landing on its shores in the late nineteenth century, you emerge from vibrant blue waves. A gateway between Asia and Australia, this Dutch colony is a key stopping point for British telegraph cables. In 1871 a link to Darwin was landed here, connecting Australia to the rest of the world through Java’s shores. While more a century in the future, surfers will travel from around the world to ride Banyuwangi’s waves, nineteenth-century cablemen complain that its waters were “uninviting” because of the “ever-present danger of crocodiles and sharks.” Here the cable intersects both turbulent waters and an ancient spiritual history. From the sixteenth to eighteenth century, the city was the capital of the Hindi Kingdom of Blambangan, which controlled the eastern tip of Java before it was taken over by the Dutch. To dig a trench for the telegraph cable to Singapore, native convicts were employed as laborers. But when they unearthed a Hindu Temple from 700 AD, the laborers refused to continue and women, who reportedly were unaffected by the native “superstitions,” had to be called in to complete the job.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikivoyage contributors, “Banyuwangi,” Wikivoyage, accessed June 3, 2013, http://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/Banyuwangi.
Wikipedia contributors, “Banyuwangi (city),” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 3, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banyuwangi_(city).

“1871 Java – Port Darwin Cable,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 3, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Cables/1871Java-PortDarwin/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “Imagine yourself in a black room, with most of the light and air cut off by screens, and blinds, a mirror lamp burning close to you, and a temperature of about 95 in the shade,” recounts one cable worker of his time in Darwin. Conditions were rough for the early operators at Australia’s first undersea telegraph station, which hooked the continent into the colonial network in 1871. In the summer the temperature was often over 100 degrees Fahrenheit, even despite the Hindu and Aboriginal servants employed to “waft away the heat.” The quarters of the telegraph men frequently flooded and stores ran out of rations. When the cable was first landed, the men’s quarters had not even been built, and for two years they lived in tents. During this time the terrestrial cable linking Darwin to Adelaide went out frequently, cut by Aborigines across the continent. Even despite the hardships, the cablemen were still a privileged lot in this colonial outpost. Their rooms, once built, were “lofty,” and their station was eventually furnished with amenities like a piano and billiard table. “Perhaps the the greatest luxury they can boast of,” one reported, “is plenty of water gratis, for which others have to pay ninepence per bucket.”

In 1908 the Dutch-German cable ship Von Podbielski finally reached Makassar, a small settlement on the Island of Celebes, “nearly half of which is still almost unknown,” or at least it was to colonial powers. The presumed half empty island was joined with the wider communications network in the Dutch East Indies in large part due to the thriving coffee crops under cultivation in the region.

“The trees obscure the houses near the beach, making it difficult to distinguish the port,” warns a British steamship captain in 1910. His description of Buleleng also notes the twin telegraph cables connecting the town to other Dutch colonies across the Bali Sea and to the nearby island province of West Nusa Teggara. In the 1840s, the Dutch performed a series of military operations in northern Bali before establishing a formal colony in Buleleng in 1882. It was their first on the island and the center of the new colonial administration. Although camouflaged by trees, the Buleleng harbor was a highly visible point on the map of international trade. By the late nineteenth century, dozens of European ships and hundreds of local vessels carrying rice, coffee, spices, vanilla, and tobacco came through the port every year.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Port Facilities No. 6: Indian Ocean. Washington: U.S. Hydrographic Office under the authority of the Secretary of the Navy, 1911. 8.
Robert Cribb and Audrey Kahin, Historical Dictionary of Indonesia (Second Edition). Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2004. 40.
Robert Cribb, Historical Atlas of Indonesia. Surrey: Curzon, 2000. 120.
Willard A. Hanna, Bali Chronicles. Singapore: Periplus, 2004. 128.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like so many Indonesian cities, Makassar developed under the influence of European spice trades beginning in the 16th century. The Dutch came in the 17th century and the cables began to arrive in the late 19th century, connecting this city with Bali in 1888, Balikpapan in 1905, and then with Java and Central Sulawesi in 1913. Arriving along the cable at the turn of the twentieth century, you witness the height of Dutch development: they had captured, rebuilt, and renamed the city’s central fort. The new “Fort Rotterdam” looked very much like its namesake, with manicured lawns and large stone buildings with pitched red roofs. The walled city that developed around the fort was a hub for the copra, rattan, pearls, trepang, and sandalwood trade, and enslaved local people for businessmen. Although Joseph Conrad called Makassar “the prettiest and perhaps, cleanest looking of all the towns in the islands,” such beauty reflected colonial interests.

In September 1901, the Dutch East Indies government constructed a cable between Banjarmasin and Java as part of a new Dutch-German agreement “for the purpose of establishing telegraphic communication with their Colonial possessions in Asia.”

Known as the “River City,” Banjarmasin is situated at the intersection of the Martapura and Barito rivers on Borneo’s southern coast. In the seventeenth century, the country’s rich natural resources—including gold, pepper, and gambier (a plant with medicinal properties)—were transported by river and sold in the natural harbor to Chinese, British, and Dutch traders. Native craftsmen were famous for their flat-bottomed wooden vessels, which carried goods through the city’s network of canals. After they secured a trade monopoly, the Dutch made Banjarmasin the capital of Borneo in the late 1700s. Soon thereafter, the electrical flows of telegraph communication joined the liquid and trade flows that defined the city’s pre-colonial history.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
“Telegraph and Telephone Notes.” The Electrical Review 53.1,340 (9 Oct. 1903): 588.
H.B.M. Government, Military Report on the Netherlands’ Possessions in the East Indies. 1919. 100.
Robert Cribb and Audrey Kahin, Historical Dictionary of Indonesia (Second Edition). Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2004. 43-4.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

Port Alberni draws its wealth from the vast forest of British Columbia’s shores. Deep inland, sheltered from the Pacific Ocean by a long, narrow inlet, the town’s early dwellers worked at waterfront mills, stripping the woods around them to make products that circled the globe. By the 1960s, many residents worked for MacMillan Bloedel, one of the world’s largest forestry companies. It not only boosted the region’s economy, but created a social world. Each of its divisions had its own social club which organized gatherings of all kinds and structured local life. Yet in the 1960s and 70s, a new constituency began to oppose the logging of Vancouver Island. Environmentalists called for the protection of nature and the establishment of parks. When the first undersea telephone link, COMPAC, arrived in 1963, environmentalists clashed with the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Service, since the company had cleared forest to make way for their system. As signals come ashore today, however, surfacing amidst logs and swerving uphill next to the Alberni Plywood Division, they face little resistance.

Trans-Pacific Cable 4 was put in the water in 1991, only a few years after TPC-3 was laid, yet it doubled the capacity of the earlier system. As the first fiber cable that linked directly from the USA to Japan, it was also the last system to be landed on Canada's west coast. After it was withdrawn from service in 2003, the Port Alberni station ceased to operate transoceanic systems.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Softbank Telecom,  NTT,  Telstra,  Verizon Business,  AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You can journey to the village of Maruyama along cables from the U.S., Australia, or various sites in Southeast Asia. But upon reaching the station, you may feel as if you’ve traveled even farther—and back in time. Across the road is Rosemary Park, a detailed replica of a sixteenth-century English town. Built in 1997 by British architects, the tourist attraction includes a working windmill, formal gardens, a duck pond, and a recreation of Shakespeare’s childhood home, complete with lifelike statues and time-specific furnishings. Shakespeare referenced rosemary in his plays, and Maruyama is known for producing this and other herbs. While the park looks to the past, the modern cable station is one of Japan’s most popular landing sites. Both enact a kind of virtual transit to far-off locales.

Bondi Beach is perhaps better known as a world famous surfing locale than as a hotspot for undersea cables. Since the early twentieth century, however, Bondi has been the landing point for numerous telegraph, telephone, and fiber-optic cable systems. Located close to the center of Sydney, Bondi offers proximity for cable companies that seek to move in close to downtown markets. The most difficult part for cable layers is getting from the coastal beaches where cables land to the cable station, located in the center of the city. Given the lack of duct space under the streets, it is difficult to pave new paths in major urban areas.

The Australia-Japan Cable (AJC) links the two countries via Guam. When it was completed in 2001, it became “Australia’s largest connection yet to the global information highways,” according to an industry newsletter. The cable reaches depths of over 9,000 meters and forms a “collapsed ring” structure with twin lines spanning each leg of the system. A private company owned by Japanese and Australian telecoms was set up to design, build, and operate the cable until its projected retirement in 2026.

Entering service in 1990 and since decommissioned, the Hong Kong-Japan-Korea (HJK) cable system connected Deep Water Bay, Hong Kong and Chikura, Japan with a branch to Jeju Island, South Korea. It was built by Fujitsu Limited (with AT&T as a subcontractor) and, along with the TPC-3, GPT, and HonTai cables, formed a “redundant fiber loop” in the South Pacific.

Moving across this cable landing, you are careful not to sink into the ditches that dot the landscape. Trash clutters the beach, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of Fiji's capital city, Suva. Yet unlike many contemporary cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the building. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing, where the company imagined new kinds of business relationships would emerge. As you pass through, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers. This is a place for meeting, for connecting, and for understanding cable history. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

There are only a few ways to get ashore at Norfolk Island. Rough seas batter the island’s high, rocky walls. There are no harbors or ports. Strong currents make entry difficult at the one feasible cable landing site, Anson Bay, and even here landslides can take out the hillside. Despite these difficulties, the island was determined to be the only feasible geographic location to land the first transpacific cable after it snaked down from Fiji and before it branched off to Australia and New Zealand. Norfolk’s inaccessibility had once made it an ideal location for a convict settlement, yet this had been closed almost fifty years prior to the cable’s arrival. Migrants from Pitcairn, the descendants of the Bounty mutineers, have taken up residence in the penal buildings. The island’s insularity coupled with a lack of cable traffic produced a set of unique connections here. For a period of time, the cableman on night duty in Southport would send newspaper extracts to Norfolk Island, where they were typed up by the operator and “tacked up on a tree at the crossroads for all to read.” This news source was known as the “Tree of Knowledge.” By the 1920s, with the development of automatic relays, far fewer staff were needed on Norfolk Island and the cable community diminished.

Laid in 1984 as a replacement for the COMPAC system, ANZCAN was the last major transpacific coaxial system. After this, fiber-optic technologies drastically increased the amount of capacity that could be carried and made the system obsolete by 2002.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: OPT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: While early telegraph cables to Australia landed far outside Nouméa, the 2008 link to Sydney was brought into the industrial heart of New Caledonia’s capital and largest city. Owned by the Postal and Telecommunications Office, the station sits on a small, south-facing cove adjacent to a notoriously overcrowded prison and the French colony’s main container port, opened in 2006. Across the bay is a massive smelting plant that processes nearly a quarter of the global nickel supply. As container vessels depart with metal bound for Australia, Japan, and Europe, cruise ships arrive carrying tourists into the city. At the University of New Caledonia, located a short walk from the cable station, degrees are granted in French literature, network administration, and extractive metallurgy, among other subjects.

Oxford Falls is a center of coordination, a place where seemingly opposed forces depend on one another: human and non-human, wired and wireless, and major telecommunications competitors. A relatively rural area north of Sydney, Oxford Falls was a satellite gateway well before it was a hub for wired infrastructure. In 1987, the government-owned Overseas Telecommunication Commission selected this valley for a satellite earth station in part because the surrounding forest, densely vegetated with native species, naturally protected aerial signals from radiointerference. Eight years later, the earth station’s major competitor, Optus, set up a second facility just down the road. As nature shielded human communication and as competitors paved the way for one another, wireless forms also set the stage for wired links. In the years that followed, major international cable networks terminated in Oxford Falls, interconnecting with rather than eliminating the older satellite arrays.

Planned and built over the course of seven years, this cable sponsored by the New Caledonia Postal and Telecommunications Office joined the French territory to a hub in North Sydney in 2008. It’s named after the southern super-continent that broke away from Pangaea roughly 200 million years ago and which included what are now Africa, Australia, South America, and Antarctica. While it doesn’t bundle multiple continents, the cable did bring New Caledonia into the modern underwater network, boosting local connection speeds well beyond existing satellite links.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Rostelecom,  KDDI

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Having built two previous cable systems across the Sea of Japan, Rostelecom and KDDI launched the dual-line Russia-Japan Cable Network in September 2008, only a few months after competing telecom operators established a northern link from Hokkaido to Sakhalin. Combined with Russia’s terrestrial cable system, RJCN boasts a latency of less than 200 milliseconds between Tokyo and London, faster than both Pacific/U.S. and Indian Ocean routes.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

According to Maori legend, New Zealand's North Island is a giant fish dragged up from the sea. Wellington, in the south, is the fish's head, and Northland, where Doubtless Bay lies, is the tail. The bay's name, however, comes from more recent sailors. When Captain James Cook sailed by the inlet in 1769, the weather made it difficult to enter and he recorded it "doubtless a bay." In 1902, in part because of its northern location, the first transpacific cable was landed here. The cable layers initially considered the Parengarenga Harbour, closer to the island's North Cape, but the location was too far from populated areas. Ahipara, on the west coast, was also considered, but this too was far from any existing telegraph lines. Although Doubtless Bay - far enough north, yet still possessing infrastructure - was established as a final middle ground, it was eventually replaced by Auckland as the entry point for New Zealand's northward-bound signal traffic. The remnants of the cable, rendered inoperational over a century ago, continue to surface periodically on the beach and pieces have been cut out of it for the regional museum. Parts of the cable complex also remain: they have been carted inland to house the area's cinema theater.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

The Okinawa - Luzon - Hong Kong cable, like others of the 1970s, was given an acronym that combined the first letters of the places that were connected: OLUHO. It was not until the fiber-optic period and the break-up of the consortium system that this naming practice began to shift to use more symbolic and less descriptive terms.

You have landed on the shores of Okinawa Island, just one island in an archipelago about 300 miles south of the rest of Japan and only 200 miles northeast of Taiwan. Geographically and politically separated from the other Japanese islands, Okinawa remained more or less self-governing until the Meiji Restoration, when it became a target for Japan’s expansionist aims. After winning the Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Japan immediately began laying cables to its colonial territories, including one that linked to Taiwan via Okinawa. For this endeavor, Japan even built its own cable ship, the Okinawa Maru. Following the massive destruction of World War II, Okinawa remained a cable hub, but the station was located far from the island's commercial center, perceived as more vulnerable to attack. Unlike the expansionist telegraph network, the coaxial and fiber-optic projects were collaborative international endeavors. Kokusai Denshin Denwa, Japan’s telecommunications company, partnered with American, Filipino, Chinese, and Korean companies to make Okinawa a stop on numerous transoceanic networks. Several cables continue to have a life even after they became obsolete, now carrying geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: For roughly two decades beginning in the late 1970s, this small village in the northwest Philippines was linked to the urban centers of Singapore, Hong Kong, and Okinawa. By 1980, Currimao was considered one of the largest and most advanced cable hubs in the region, well-staffed by cablemen who maintained its terminal equipment, power plant, and cable lines. But when the Asia-America Gateway system was being built in the early 2000s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company selected a landing site more than a hundred miles south in the province of La Union, closer to Metro Manila. As quickly as it appeared, Currimao faded from the network map and the former station was transformed into a museum. Today the town is perhaps best known for a series of coral rock formations, shaped by the ocean into dramatic caverns and spires over thousands of years.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Popular with surfers and backpackers, the small fishing village of Cherating lies approximately twenty miles north of Kuantan on the central east coast of Malaysia. Every spring and summer, leatherback sea turtles swim through the calm waters and lay their eggs on broad sand beaches lined with Casuarina trees. These same environmental conditions are well suited to underwater cable landings: sand is an accommodating medium for cable burial and there are no strong ocean currents to shift or expose cables once in place. Although cables have connected here since the 1980s, the current station was built as part of Telekom Malaysia’s investment in the APCN-2 system of the early 2000s. A single-story complex with pitched roofs set back from the road and surrounded by a security fence, the Cherating cable station is relatively unassuming. But a large communications tower, visible for miles, marks the site as a hub for signal traffic.

In 2012, a consortium of telecom companies led by China Unicom signed a construction and maintenance agreement for the Asia-Pacific Gateway (APG) cable system, due to open in 2015. The system is specially routed to avoid areas prone to seismic activity while providing additional capacity along the region’s existing international networks.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Telstra

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Linking their country to the US lines in Hawai’i, Australia’s largest telecommunications provider, Telstra, built this cable in 2008 at the estimated cost of $300 million AUD. As Telstra's COO notes, the cable serves to ”significantly reduce Australia's reliance on foreign-owned companies in order to compete globally."

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom,  PCCW,  Telstra

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Some locals think these spectacular rock formations resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of its beaches. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

A seventy-foot whale skeleton occupies a public plaza in central Wada. This small town outside Tokyo is also home to a dedicated landing station for the FLAG North Asian Loop cable, a kind of underwater skeletal system for communication in Asia. While the station is relatively new, whaling has been central to the area's culture and economy since the early 1600s. Today, Wada is one of only two places in Japan where it’s still permitted, and efforts are made to keep the tradition alive despite international bans. Every June, local schoolchildren gather to watch the first whale being brought ashore and butchered, followed by a community meal of fried whale, rice, and watermelon. Optical cables land far more discretely but in growing numbers along this stretch of the outer Bōsō Peninsula, now crowded with cable stations. Although across the Pacific, cable companies have to worry about people digging up their land lines, the coastal area of Wada is safe. Because of the local culture, one cableman says, people stick by their agreements to stay off the route that the telecommunications company bought. As a result, they have only needed to install a single line between the cable station and the landing point, compared to the redundant lines that must be extended everywhere else.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: FLAG North Asia Loop/REACH North Asia Loop

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: FLAG North Asian Loop a.k.a. Reach North Asian Loop, jointly developed by India’s Global Cloud Xchange (formerly FLAG Telecom) and China’s Reach Global Services, has one of the largest cable capacities in Asia. The system’s two fiber loops connect Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan and were completed in 2001 and 2002.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it was finished in December 2005, the consortium-owned Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 4 cable provided both additional bandwidth and greater redundancy along the bulk of the previous-generation SeaMeWe-3 line between the Mediterranean and Singapore. SeaMeWe-3, however, extends significantly further to points in China, Japan, Australia, the U.K., and Germany, among others.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A futuristic cable station sits next to the expansive wetlands of the Dongtan national wildlife sanctuary. Signals arrive through major underwater networks, while swans, cranes, spoonbills, shorebirds, and many species of fish stop here along their migratory routes. Like the landing station, Chongming Island’s salt-water marshes and tidal flats are transitional zones that mediate between land and sea. Although it feels rural, the island is only twenty miles from central Shanghai and is connected by a freeway. Visitors fill the tree-lined boardwalks that crisscross the reserve, observing the local fauna. Meanwhile, data is surveilled as it passes through the station: a white sign with red text marks the presence of underground cables and bears the name “PLA Unit 61398,” a group believed to engage in electronic monitoring and cyber-attacks against the United States.

Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.

In the early 1890s, two major infrastructures latched Medan into global networks: the Port of Belawan and an undersea communications cable. Only seventy years before, Medan had been a village of only 200, but in the intervening years it quickly expanded as a center of trade. Massive amounts of tobacco were harvested from Dutch plantations and shipped out of Medan’s port, including the much-desired Deli leaf for cigar wrapping. When tobacco farming pushed the soil’s limits, American companies created rubber plantations, some encompassing tens of thousands of acres. At one point, the United States Rubber Company held 150 square miles of land and employed fourteen thousand indentured laborers. The social and environmental ramifications of the plantations were huge. Large swathes of forest were cleared by Chinese and native laborers, the rural peasantry was left without land, and chemical fertilizers were spread across the ground. Though the city is no longer under Dutch rule, the colonial infrastructure had a lasting impact. Plantation-financed colonial architecture remains, and coffee, rubber, and palm oil estates continue to devastate the forests. Enormous container ships load their exports at the Port of Belawan, now the second busiest port in Indonesia. And undersea cables, as in the nineteenth century, link Medan’s economy and culture into a global system.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.
