http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The South Africa-Far East (SAFE) cable system, built in 2002 by a U.S. company, traverses the Indian Ocean on a path similar to the one taken by Portuguese explorers in the fifteenth century. By joining the SAT-3/WASC cable at Melkbosstrand, South Africa, SAFE provides a direct optical fiber link between Western Europe and Malaysia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Globe Telecom,  Google,  KDDI,  Telkom Indonesia,  SingTel,  China Telecom,  TOT,  China Mobile,  Chunghwa Telecom,  Brunei International Gateway

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Shantou is a hub in four international cable networks, all built since the late 1990s. From your point of arrival on Longhu Beach, this state-of-the-art China Telecom facility could be mistaken for one of the many resort hotels that line the waterfront. Yet the new technology and luxury tourism of Shantou lies only twenty miles from Guiyu, a town that has been called “the electronic-waste capital of the globe.” Every year, the city receives over 1.5 million pounds of discarded computers and other electronics, most of it from overseas. Tens of thousands of laborers strip cables and dismantle circuit boards to extract valuable metals, but the toxic byproducts of these machines have devastated the workers’ health and surrounding environment.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

Completed in early 1906, the Yokohama-Bonin cable was part of a system linking Japan and the United States, with stopovers on several Pacific islands. As the journal Telegraph Age reports that year: “Bonin has recently been connected to Yokohama by a cable of English manufacture which the Japanese government has been laying with its own cable-ship, the Okinawa Maru. . . . The work was finished in twelve days without the least hitch, and the signals through the cable when laid were excellent.”

The port of Yokohama was a modest fishing village until the 1850s, when it was opened to foreign trade under pressure from the United States. Rapid development followed, transforming Yokohama into an international center of commerce. Japan’s first overland telegraph line linked Yokohama’s Court House station with neighboring Tokyo in 1869. Thirty-five years later, a submarine cable arrived from the Bonin Islands, bringing the city into communication with San Francisco more than 5,000 miles away. But the Great Kantō earthquake of 1923 devastated the city, including its nascent cable infrastructure. As a local newspaper reports, a tsunami swallowed boats in the harbor, fires swept through the streets, and “the telegraph building, in which most of the wires radiating to all parts of the island terminated, was completely demolished, leaving the telegraph system in a hopeless condition.” Yokohama was soon rebuilt, only to suffer more damage during the air raids of World War II.

On some islands, even finding a shore on which to land one’s cable is a fraught process. Located about 1,000 miles south east of Japan, the Bonin Islands have steep coastlines that make landing difficult. Rocky mountainsides rise up from the blue-green sea, gradually turning from stone into lush greenery higher in the sky. In some spots, small strips of sand slice between the ocean and the hills. In the early 1900s, a cable landed on one of these remote beaches, connecting Guam (and thereby the United States) to Japan. The Japanese had claimed the land only a few decades earlier, and about forty settlers made their homes on the previously uninhabited islands. An American company sent British ships and workers here to land the cable, all of whom were tentatively but amicably received. Like the small beaches that join the water and land, the Bonin Islands were a small but essential solder point between the U.S. and Japan, mediating communication between these two distant societies.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Before Hong Kong was handed back to China, one author observed that it was a “center of espionage, a hive of spies,” with up to 5,000 intelligence agents seeking information for countries around the world. In 1977, the British GCHQ built a satellite base at Chung Hom Kok, on Hong Kong’s less populated southern coast. For over a decade, the satellite base, code-named “Project Kittiwake,” was a center for monitoring Chinese communications and nuclear tests. It was scanned communications about events such as the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. When Hong Kong was transferred back to China, Project Kittiwake was moved and the site razed, leaving little for the Chinese to see. At the turn of the century, the Chinese government invested in Chung Hom Kok’s external communications – it was designated a “telecentre” for the development of satellite and submarine connections. Today a new undersea cable station, poised on the edge of a hill and overlooking small fishing boats that dot the waters, still monitors traffic. Rather than intercepting signals sent through the air, communications are now filtered before they are allowed to enter mainland China.

In 1900, the village of Naic in Cavite Province was joined to an offshore island by underwater telegraph cable as part of a U.S. Army Signal Corps operation to network the area around Manila. A century later, Naic became a landing site for EAC-C2C, bringing it into direct communication with the U.S. and several Asian countries. Owned by the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT), the station is located on the town’s outskirts near farmland, subdivisions, and a vast new horseracing complex with stables for 800 thoroughbreds. Even though they are broadcast online, spectators travel from as far as Manila to witness the races first-hand, a popular activity in the Philippines since the late nineteenth century. Some have even described the local telecommunications market, dominated by PLDT and Globe Telecom, as a two-horse race.

EAC-C2C represents the merger of the EAC (East Asia Crossing) and C2C (City-to-City) cable networks, completed in 2007 by Pacnet. Together, they form Asia’s largest privately owned cable system with a total of seventeen landing sites across Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Singapore.
In 1932, the shore end of the cable was moved north from Wellington to Muriwai Beach, outside of Auckland. As New Zealand's commercial traffic moved northward, so did the cables.

On New Zealand’s rural west coast, a coaxial cable extends out from a sand bank, over a small pond of water, and back into the beach before it heads to Sydney. Aquatic creatures have incorporated its eroding armor and still strong copper core into their home. Old cables dating to the telegraph era have surfaced on this beach: the first international link landed over a century ago, in 1912. Cost-cutting during the Depression prompted the cable company to re-locate a second link, formerly in Wellington, here in 1932. From Muriwai cables extend inland over twenty miles to the growing city of Auckland. This terrestrial path is almost as fraught as the surf-beaten shores of Muriwai. In 1952, incorrectly gauging the location of the cable system, a road grader severed the international network for five hours. After this, the cable companies ensured that the network was marked extensively for the local community.

“On December 15,” declares a U.S. trade report, “the Eastern Telegraph Co.’s new cable from Penang to Colombo was established and its new cable system thrown open to traffic with London and with the Far East.” This 1913 cable was part of a much longer 12,000-mile connection between Lands End, England and Hong Kong (via Suez, Aden, Colombo, Penang, and Singapore). By avoiding slower overland lines and stopping points where a message has to be deciphered and retransmitted, the submarine cable greatly increased the speed and reliability of communication between Britain and its settlements in Asia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This 300-mile cable connects northern Japan to Russia’s terrestrial cable system, providing a shorter path between Japan and Europe compared to southern oceanic routes. It was completed in 2008 and is jointly owned by Japan’s NTT Corporation and TransTelekom of Russia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT,  TTK

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The remote village of Ishikari flourished in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries as a center of salmon fishing. One of its oldest standing structures is a 1694 shrine dedicated to the fish deity Same-sama. But as catches steadily declined in the 1900s, Ishikari expanded to become a shipping and communications gateway for the larger neighboring city of Sapporo. The first ship to arrive in the new harbor in 1982 was the Blanca Rainier from Sakhalin carrying 3,500 tons of raw timber. A ceremony held the next day marked the port’s entry into international freight circuits. Twenty-six years later, a fiber-optic cable was laid along the same path, joining Russian and Japanese networks. Today, Ishikari is by far Japan’s northernmost cable station and the only landing site on the island of Hokkaido.

Part of an alternate route between European and Asian hubs, the HSCS first connected Japan’s Hokkaido and Russia’s Sakhalin in 2008. While the route boasts improved speeds and latency handling over the old network pathways, its construction in large part responds to the outages caused in 2006 by an undersea earthquake in Taiwan and the subsequent need for more redundancies in the region's cable connections.

This northern suburb of Auckland, New Zealand, has been an outlet for northward communications for more than a century. In 1912, after a new Chief Post Office was opened in central Auckland, the Pacific Cable Board re-directed their cable from rural Doubtless Bay to Takapuna Beach. The workers from the station came with the cable, and the cable station was set up on in the Post Office, consolidating networks formerly distributed across the land. As the cable continued to function without major disruptions, networks in the following decades continued to follow the same path. When the Southern Cross Internet cable was set up in 2000, it too landed on the Takapuna shore. In the cable industry, the prevailing logic is to go with the tried and true.

The Hawai'i-2 telephone cable was the second link between the United States mainland and Hawai'i. Extended in 1964, it connected to a transpacific link that shuttled signals onward to Japan. For the system, a new station was constructed on O'ahu's west shore, which would become a critical hub for internet signals half a century later.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, and linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The volcanic island of Jeju, meaning “province across the sea,” sits sixty miles off the coast of South Korea. Before the island became more closely linked to the mainland by tourism and underwater cables, it had a distinct language, culture, and ocean-based economy. Female free divers known as “haenyeo,” or “sea women,” have gathered shellfish and other marine life from the Korea Strait for generations, though their numbers are dwindling. In the 1990s, Jeju became a landing site for undersea electrical and communication lines. A branch of the Hong Kong-Japan-Korea (HJK) system surfaced on Jeju's shores in 1990, and in 1996, a high-voltage cable joined the island’s power grid to the Korean Peninsula. With the decommissioning of HJK, Jeju fell out of the international cable circuit, redirecting all signal traffic through mainland hubs.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: American Samoa Government,  Elandia

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Propelled by a strong wind, you land on a small, white sand beach dotted with coconut palms and volcanic rock formations in the southern part of Tutulia Island. This spot is now linked to Hawai'i by underwater cable, but the same connection was once made by air. During World War II, the U.S. Navy built an airfield here, which was later converted to receive passenger jets. By the 1960s, it had become a key stopping point for flights between Australia and Hawai‘i. As planes grew larger in the 1980s, however, they started to land at the expanded airport in nearby Samoa or bypass the islands entirely, no longer needing to refuel midway along their journeys. Today, the runways are mostly used by military and cargo transports with only the occasional passenger flight, making the U.S. territory feel remote. The cable didn’t do much to change this, since few locals can afford the steep Internet fees.

This two-part cable system links American 'Samoa and Samoa to Keawa'ula, Hawai'i, where it joins networks reaching the U.S. mainland, Southeast Asia, and Australia. To lower costs, the system repurposed sections of the PacRim East cable between Hawai'i and New Zealand, built in the 1990s as one of the first fiber-optic trans-Pacific links and retired in 2007. Despite being nearly 20 years old, the cable provides more than enough capacity for these small island groups.

The Pacific Cable Board cable was laid in 1902. It had been imagined for decades before it could actually be laid. It was only once the British came to value strategic communications that Sanford Fleming, a Canadian, was able to push the project through.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pacnet

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center.) Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Along the shores of the Pearl River, across from Hong Kong, Macau was a fishing village until Portuguese traders, seeking a place to dry and store goods, established themselves there in the mid-16th century. Commodities were not the only things traded: in the same period Macau was a key node in the trafficking of Chinese slaves to Portugal. Even after the enslavement of the Chinese was outlawed, slavery remained an ever-present part of social life. In the early 1600s, there were approximately 6 slaves, the majority of whom had been brought from Africa, for every Portuguese family. Portuguese shacks grew only gradually into a settlement, and it was not until after the opium wars of the 19th century that China ceded the right of governance and occupation in exchange for a promise that Portugal would assist in levying a tax on the drug. Only a few years before, in 1884, a telegraph cable linked Macau to Hong Kong, across the bay. The island remained under Portuguese control until 1999, making it the last remaining European colony in Asia. That year, it was both transferred back to China, and linked via a modern undersea cable system, SEA-WE-ME-3, which revived the earlier connection to Hong Kong.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Built in the 1970s, the Nanhui station was the first landing site for international coaxial cables in China. Early signals surfaced on the muddy shores of Nanhui district, then mostly farmland, roughly thirty miles southeast of central Shanghai. Now the area is almost unrecognizable, transformed by rapid industrialization that has displaced many of its former inhabitants. Large-scale development projects have even altered the local geography, continuing a process begun millennia ago when Nanhui was formed by silt deposited at the mouth of the Yangtze River. New cables pass by a huge artificial island that contains the recently constructed Shanghai deep-water container port, linked to the mainland by a twenty-mile bridge. And just east of the station, an entire city for 800,000 is being built from scratch on land reclaimed from Hangzhou Bay.

The Australia-Papua New Guinea cable was laid between Port Moresby and Cairns in 1975, becoming operational in 1976. The cable, like many others of this generation, outlasted its design life, serving Papua New Guinea until it was replaced by APNG-2 in 2006.

Annexed by Queensland in the 1880s, Papua New Guinea's capital has long been subject to Australian oversight. Yet while colonists maintained a military and administrative presence on the island, they provided few public works or services. The first cables were laid during the 1940s, but were not intended to carry indigenous communications. Instead, they served the Australian Navy. Stretching only a few kilometers out to sea, these armored cables served to detect the presence of Japanese submarines and predict potential invasions. Although the cables were dismantled after two years, Australia continued to administer the region until 1975, the year Papua New Guinea both gained independence and received its first transoceanic cable: APNG. Today, Port Moresby remains an important link in the chain between old and new forms of colonization. Corporations follow in the footsteps of colonial powers, pouring economic investments into the area, always with strings attached. ExxonMobil has begun a billion dollar liquid natural gas operation in the north of the country, creating undersea pipe networks that host both fuel and communications. The APNG-2 fiber-optic cable, one of Papua New Guinea’s newest transoceanic connections, surfaces on Ela Beach, following the exact path as its predecessors.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: David Fickling, “Raskol gangs rule world's worst city,” The Guardian, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2004/sep/22/population.davidfickling.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: From a mostly undeveloped beach several miles north of Miyazaki, you follow a dirt path inland until it opens onto a single-lane road. In the distance, a ringed communications tower is visible above the treetops. Homing in on this beacon, you reach a windowless building surrounded on all sides by a barbed-wire fence. Three majestic palm trees and a plaque bearing the logo of Japanese telecom company KDDI mark the entrance, while farmland and greenhouses occupy the surrounding plots. In 1977, the first telephone cable arrived from Okinawa, where a trans-Pacific link to the U.S. had recently been completed. Optical cables followed in the 1990s, but more recent connections have overlooked Miyazaki in favor of the cluster of hubs along the east coast of Honshu Island.

Established in 1997, the Asia-Pacific Cable Network (APCN) spans more than 7,400 miles and connects Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand. A telecom consortium (including AT&T, Alcatel-Lucent, and KDD Submarine Cable Systems) owns this regional trunk-and-branch network.
